posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
One of the Spark Max’s on our Max Swerve drive train has a fault/sticky fault for Sensor Fault, and we can’t seem to get it to go away.  It’s on one of the NEO 550’s, with the Through Bore encoder attached with the adapter board.  Using the stock sample code Rev provided for the Max Swerve.

We’ve tried swapping the Neo for a new one, but that didn’t seem to work.  We don’t have a spare Through Bore encoder to try swapping that, unfortunately.  All of the wires for both the Neo and Encoder (Stock encoder wire that came with the Max Swerve module) pass visual inspection, and the terminals are all seated well in each device.

Anyone have any advice? Maybe @Greg_Needel ?  We emailed into support late last night, but figured it wouldn’t hurt to ask here as well while we wait for a reply.

posts.name: Mack
posts.cooked: Have you attempted restoring the SPARK MAX to factory default settings and testing the SPARK MAX by running the NEO 550 through the REV Hardware Client without the Through Bore Encoder connected?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Have you tried turning it off and back on again?

posts.custom_user_title: Have you tried turning it off and back on again?

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: Yes, we did.  We spent most of last night in the hardware client, tried it with the encoder attached and unattached, as well as the second Neo 550.  Tried resetting, burning flash, and clearing sticky faults all multiple times, unfortunately.

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked: There is a little switch on the through bore, can you make sure its on ‘A’. Also do you get any data back on the telemetry tab for either the through bore of the motor encoder. This should tell you which sensor has a fault.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: It is - I checked that last night.  The switch is in the up position, looks the same as the other modules (all of which are fine).  We also toggled it back and forth just to make sure.

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked: Well the telemetry will tell you for sure which of the two sensors is at fault here.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: Make sure the board is connected correctly. We found that the connector on the board is undersized and it fits into the controller’s dataport on the wrong pins. It took us a while to figure that one out.

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
We’ll, we triple checked everything and tried going through the factory defaults, reset sticky fault process a few times with no luck.  Can confirm the through bore encoder was not the issue, as we couldn’t get it to work when it was completely unplugged.

Ended up taking one off an old robot and tried it, worked perfectly with the original motor, through bore encoder, cable and adapter board.  At this point, it looks like that spark might be bad - I’m just not sure if it’s one we ordered in the fall, or one we got from FIRST after winning a drawing for filling out the KOP questionnaire last year…

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
